data.text: Introduction

The Trusts recognise that the attraction and retention of employees with certain skills and experience is critical to the provision of an efficient, high quality service that achieves the best possible health outcomes for patients, at a sustainable cost.

There is an understanding that throughout an employee's working life, there may be times when a change in personal circumstances make it difficult for them to continue working their contractual hours or work pattern. Alternatively, employees may decide that they wish to pursue other interests or activities alongside their working lives and wish to adjust their work commitments to better accommodate them. At these times, the Trusts wish to support the employee by considering flexible working options.

Furthermore, flexible working arrangements enable the Trusts to be responsive to the changing demands of services to meet the needs of service users; providing increased access to our high quality services. Where it is the Trusts that are seeking to introduce or extend the flexibility of employee working hours, location or shift pattern(s), this will be through consultation and in line with the Trusts' Organisational Change policy.
Requests for reasonable adjustments to working hours associated with an underlying health condition or disability should be dealt with under the Trusts' Sickness Absence policy and procedure.
Purpose
The purpose of this policy is to set out the Trusts framework for managing requests for flexible working that comply with best practice and is based on the ACAS statutory Code of Practice.
This policy aims to:-
Explain the rights of employees to request to work flexibly
Provide a clear and manageable procedure for dealing with requests for flexible working
Provide the basis for a clear understanding of the benefit to the Trusts and the employee of flexible working arrangements
Make clear the responsibilities of the manager and the employees.
Scope

This policy applies to all employees of Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust (BTUH), Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust (MEHT) and Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust (SUHT) including Medical and Dental staff. It does not apply to Contractors, Bank staff, Agency or Volunteer workers.
It does not form part of the employee's contract of employment but is a statement of the Trust's current practice and may be changed from time to time.
Eligibility

Since June 2014, all employees who have worked for an employer continuously for 26 weeks have the right to ask their employer if they can work flexibly – that might be to do with their hours, times or place of work.
Employees who are not eligible to make a statutory request for flexible working may still make a request under this policy and it must be given due consideration by their manager.

Managers have a legal obligation to give requests careful and serious consideration and to be as flexible as possible in accommodating them subject to the needs of the service and the employee group as a whole. Care should be taken that a manager does not inadvertently discriminate against an employee (either directly or indirectly) on the basis of a protected characteristic as defined in the Equality Act 2010. The protected characteristics are: age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion and belief, sex and sexual orientation.

There is no automatic right to work flexibly and any flexible working arrangement is a voluntary agreement between the employee and their manager. Each individual request for flexible working should be considered on its merits. Employees and managers are expected to work together in an open, flexible and consultative manner to reach an agreement that is acceptable and workable for both parties.
Definitions
For the purpose of applying the provisions contained in this policy, the following definitions shall have the following meaning:

table_items.text: The term ‘flexible working' describes a type of working arrangement which gives some degree of flexibility on how long, where and when employees work. The flexibility can be in terms of working time, working location or the pattern of working. Appendix 3 lists a number of different types of flexible working options.

Under the Equality Act 2010, it is unlawful to discriminate on the basis of nine protected characteristics. These are: age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sex, sexual orientation.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Managers
6.1.1 Managers are required to familiarise themselves with this policy enabling them to fairly and appropriately manage requests made by members of their team for flexible working.
6.1.2 Managers are required to carefully and fully consider all applications for flexible working and to complete the required paperwork in a timely fashion.

6.1.3 The manager is responsible for meeting with the employee once a formal flexible working request is submitted. This meeting and written confirmation of the outcomes must be completed within 28 calendar days of receiving the request.

6.1.4 There may be occasions where a manager cannot accommodate all the flexibility requested by the employee, however, in discussion with them, a mutually acceptable compromise position can be explored and agreed.

6.1.5 If the request is not agreed, the manager must write to the employee within 14 calendar days of the meeting setting out clear business reasons for the rejection of the request and notifying the employee of the appeals process. The letter should include the name and job title of the next-in-line manager who the employee may appeal the outcome with, should they wish to do so.
6.1.6 The manager must keep a record of flexible working applications and the outcome retained in the employee personal file.
Employees
6.2.1 Employees are expected to familiarise themselves with this policy
6.2.2 Employees should complete the flexible working request application form (appendix

1) and submit it to their manager for consideration. It is recommended that an employee discusses their wish for a flexible working arrangement with their manager ahead of submitting a formal application.
6.2.3 Employees should take into consideration the impact of their flexible working request on the team and the service.

6.2.4 Employees must give consideration to the fact that a flexible working arrangement may have contractual implications (e.g. pay, pension and other benefits) and they may wish to discuss this with Human Resources or their Trade Union representative or Professional Body. However, Human Resources and/or Trade Union representatives are not permitted to give financial advice and employees should make their own arrangements to receive financial advice.
6.2.5 Employees are entitled to have a current work colleague or Trade Union representative accompany them to a meeting with the relevant manager to discuss their flexible working request.
Human Resources
6.3.1 Human Resources are responsible for providing advice on flexible working arrangements and the relevant process to managers and their teams.
6.3.2 Human Resources are responsible for monitoring applications for flexible working and ensuring that they are managed in a fair, consistent and appropriate manner.
Procedure and time frames for Making and Considering Requests for
Flexible Working
For employees wishing to make a flexible working request, appendix 1, ‘Making a Flexible Working Request' form needs to be completed and submitted to their manager.

The manager should arrange to meet with the employee to discuss the request. The employee is allowed to be accompanied at the meeting by a Trade Union representative or current work colleague. The meeting should be arranged within 14 calendar days of receipt of the flexible working request.

At the meeting, the manager should discuss the request in detail with the employee; exploring with them how they see it working for themselves, the team and the service as a whole. Confirmation as to how long the employee wishes the arrangement to be applicable for should also be confirmed. Please see section 9 below for further details on considerations to be borne in mind before reaching a decision as to whether or not the request can be accommodated.

It may be the case that the manager does not feel able to agree to the flexible working request in its entirety, however, often a compromise position can be discussed and agreed between the employee and the manager.
The manager is required to notify the employee of their decision in writing within 14 calendar days of the meeting. This notification will either:
Accept the request and establish a start date and any other action that needs to take place prior to implementation.
Or
Confirm a compromise agreed at the meeting; Or
Reject the request and set out clear business reasons for the rejection together with notification of the appeals process.
In the event that a request for flexible working is refused or not met in full, the employee may apply again no less than 12 months from their previous request.
Records of all applications and their outcomes should be retained on personal files in accordance with national statutory documentation retention periods.
Considerations
In considering whether a request can be reasonably accommodated, the manager will have to assess the likely impact on:
Patient care or quality of service delivery;
Any savings or budgetary constraints as a result;
The extent to which the change is in the interests of the team, taking account of peaks and troughs of work;
In practice how the work will be undertaken and/or redistributed;
Whether replacement employees are likely to be required and/or available;
Whether similar requests from other team members are likely and/or could they be accommodated;
Support for other employees needed as a result of the arrangement;
How the new arrangement will be monitored and reviewed.

Whether flexible working requests can reasonably be met, either in full or in part, will be a matter of judgement, balancing the impact on the individual of declining the request with the impact on the service and the rest of the team in agreeing to the request.

The Trusts require managers to evidence that they have considered every request seriously and made a business case assessment and that they are treating all members of the team fairly and consistently. The manager will only be able to refuse a request for flexible working if they can evidence that they have considered all the following:
Any additional costs;
Ability to reorganise work amongst existing employees;
Ability to recruit additional employees;
Effect on ability to meet customer demands;
Sufficient work for the periods the employee proposes to work;
Planned structural change to the organisation.
The following should also be fully considered:-
Is the role suitable for the type of flexible working being requested;
Is the job holder eligible.

Where it is reasonably practical to do so, the manager and employees should in the first instance agree to the proposed flexible working arrangement being implemented for a defined temporary/trial period. This will help establish whether the proposed working pattern is suitable for both parties in the long term. Regular review(s) should be carried out during the temporary/trial period by the manager and employee. At the end of the temporary/trial period, a decision as to whether or not the flexible working arrangement is sustainable will be made by the manager. It will then be for the manager and the employee to agree if the flexible working arrangement will be reviewed on a regular basis going forward (e.g. every 12 months) or whether the change is a permanent one.

Should it be agreed between the manager and the employee that the flexible working arrangement should be implemented on a permanent basis, this will be a variation in contractual terms. The employee has no automatic right to change back to their previous pattern of work.
All requests, including any appeals, must be considered and decided on within the timescales detailed above and in appendix 2 unless the manager agrees to extend this period with the employee.
Appeals

All employees have the right to appeal against the formal decision regarding their flexible working request whether it be agreed only in part or refused in its entirety. The procedure to be followed is contained within the Trusts Appeals Procedure and can be summarised as follows.

If the employee wishes to appeal, he/she must do so in writing to the next-in-line manager within 14 calendar days of receipt of written notification of the original decision. The letter must clearly state the grounds of appeal. However, they are encouraged to try and resolve the situation informally first, with support from Human Resources if appropriate.
On receipt of the written appeal, the next in line manager will send a letter of acknowledgement to the employee within 10 calendar days of receipt.

In the event that an appeal is not submitted within the prescribed timescales it is received by the Trusts ‘out of time', the Trusts reserve the right to review the reasons for any delayed appeal and determine whether it will be considered.
The employee's rights to representation at the flexible working request meeting will apply equally to the appeal meeting.

The next-in-line or nominated manager should not have had any previous involvement in the decision. He/she will arrange to meet with the employee and will Chair a meeting to discuss the employees' reasons for appealing the outcome. The manager who made the original decision should provide the appeal Chair with a copy of the original flexible working request, their written management considerations and any supporting documents at least 10 calendar days before the date of the appeal meeting. The appeal meeting must be conducted within 20 working days of its receipt.
The Chair of the appeal meeting should be supported by a member of Human Resources who also has not had any previous involvement.
The Chair of the appeal meeting will write to the employee within 10 calendar days of the meeting confirming the outcome of their appeal. The decision of the appeal panel is final.
Training Requirements

This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. There are no specific training requirements. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Human Resources department.
Monitoring and Audit

All flexible working requests and their outcomes handled under this policy will be monitored by the Human Resources department in partnership with the relevant Staff-Side Representatives. The aim will be to ensure that any flexible working requests are managed appropriately as per this policy.
This policy is due to be reviewed in 3 years.

FLEXIBLE WORKING OPTIONS  Appendix 3
Job Sharing

An arrangement whereby two part-time employees share the responsibility of one full time job. In a shared responsibility arrangement, the individuals both carry out all the duties of the job, simply picking up the work where the other left off. While in a divided responsibility arrangement, the duties of the position are divided between the two individuals with each being able to provide cover for the other where necessary. The salary and terms and conditions of service are based on a pro-rata basis according to the hours worked by each job-sharer. Should one of the job sharers leave the Trusts or transfer to another role, the remaining employee may be given the option of increasing their hours to cover the whole role. If this is not possible, attempts will be made to recruit another job sharer. If this is unsuccessful, redeployment to another role may be required.
Part-time working
A system whereby the employee is contracted to work less than the normal hours of work of a comparable full-time worker. There are enormous variations to part-time working. Examples are:-
Compressed hours

This system permits employees to work their total number of contractual hours over fewer working days to compensate for the additional days off. Usually a five day week is compressed into four days or four and a half days. Alternatively, a  day fortnight compressed into 9 days.
Annualised hours

A contract in which the hours of work are spread unevenly through the year, with fewer hours worked at certain times, for example, when an area or department has regular peaks and troughs of demand during the year. The employee's salary is paid in twelve equal monthly instalments and any overpayment must automatically be repaid should they terminate their employment with any outstanding contracted hours owing by the end of their notice period.

Where possible, the manager and the employee will agree to the proposed yearly working pattern and this should be rigorously adhered to. This is to ensure that the employee works no less than the contracted hours proposed and to ensure that they meet the needs of the service.
Term time working

This is essentially an agreement to allow an employee extended unpaid holidays to coincide with school holidays. It can apply to full time and part-time employees, trading time off for a reduction in income but retaining a permanent contract. Pay is averaged over the 12 months and the contract usually specifies that no annual leave should be taken during term time. Employees are contracted throughout the year and are therefore required to confirm non-worked weeks at the beginning of the leave year; additionally report any health related absences throughout this period.
Career breaks/Sabbaticals
The employee has an extended period of time away from paid work often with a guarantee of a return to the same or a similar job at the end of the time. Please also refer to the Career Break policy.
Short term unpaid leave

Managers may grant an employee short term unpaid leave (or offer flexible work if this is preferable) for a range of reasons, e.g. to look after children during school holidays, or to care for a member of their family who is seriously ill. In these circumstances, the unpaid leave period should not exceed three months. This will be subject to the needs of the service. Employees must not undertake any paid employment during this time.

Managers should make every effort to meet such requests from employees. Where appropriate, employees may be asked to exhaust their annual leave entitlement before taking unpaid leave. In authorising the leave, the manager may consider if the employee is subject to any performance, capability or disciplinary issues.
Temporary adjustment to hours

This means voluntary reduced working for a specified period with a guarantee that he/she can return to previously contracted hours when that period ends. This is usually used to manage other short-term personal or caring commitments. Pay is reduced accordingly.
Flexitime/staggered hours

Where an employee within a team works slightly different start/finish and break times outside certain core times each day. Usually this means employees can vary their start and finish times to suit domestic responsibilities, travel arrangements or for work reasons. Employees can carry over any excess or deficit in the number of hours they are required to work to the next accounting period, subject to limits.
Homeworking

Some posts do not require the employee to be permanently on site. A combination of working at home and on site is often an option. This can be a useful short-term solution to providing assistance to an employee having to manage a change in their personal circumstances. Please also see the Trusts Homeworking policy.
Phased return to work

Used after a period of extended leave such as maternity leave, career break or after serious or prolonged illness. Normal hours of working are reduced initially on a temporary basis before returning to normal hours of work. Please also refer to the Trusts Managing Sickness Absence policy.
Flexible retirement

Flexible retirement allows Trusts and their employees to be flexible about the age at which an employee retires, the length of time taken to retire and the nature/pattern of work in the lead up to retirement.

Flexible options include: step down, wind down, retire and return, draw down, late retirement enhancement, early retirement. The options available can vary dependent on the version of the NHS pension scheme that the employee is a member of. Employees are recommended that they seek independent advice when deciding on pension and retirement options.
